title: Wireless Network Security Fundamentals: Project-Based Detection and Analysis Through Mathematical Modeling (Large-Scale)

context.prior_knowledge: Basic understanding of computer and internet usage, and foundational high school-level mathematics knowledge (statistics, probability, equations)
context.additional_context: Learners analyze simple security threat cases in real Wi-Fi environments, exploring mathematical approaches to identify anomalies through numerical characteristics of network packets and graph-based visualization, with a focus on analysis methods utilizing variables such as inter-packet intervals, protocol distribution, and data size.

learning_goals: Learners can classify over 12 common types of attacks that may occur in wireless networks based on mathematical classification criteria.
Learners can probabilistically identify anomalous patterns in network traffic using frame analysis tools (e.g., Wireshark) and statistical formulas.
Learners can complete a project to detect malicious traffic by applying mathematical models of k-NN or fuzzy logic classification.
Learners can classify attack types with over 80% accuracy through hands-on practice with real datasets and evaluate performance via a confusion matrix.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
